title: 106_s1161
content: The "Economic Sanctions Reform Act of 1999" aims to establish a framework for enacting unilateral economic sanctions legislation to serve U.S. national interests while minimizing adverse effects on businesses, exporters, farmers, and workers. The "Economic Sanctions Reform Act of 1999" defines new unilateral economic sanctions laws as any legislation enacted after the Act's date that authorizes the implementation of unilateral economic sanctions by the United States. The term "new unilateral economic sanctions legislation" refers to any bill, joint resolution, amendment, or conference report introduced after the enactment of the Act that authorizes the implementation of unilateral economic sanctions by the United States. The term "unilateral economic sanction" refers to measures taken by the United States to advance foreign policy or national security interests by constraining economic activities. The term "unilateral economic sanction" refers to measures taken by the United States to advance foreign policy or national security interests by constraining economic activities, excluding obligations under international agreements or regimes. SEC. 4. GUIDELINES FOR NEW UNILATERAL ECONOMIC SANCTIONS LEGISLATION. Any new unilateral economic sanctions legislation should include a statement of the foreign policy or national security objective, provide authority for the President to refrain from imposing or suspend sanctions if in the national interest, and ensure contract sanctity unless determined otherwise. The legislation should be in the national interest of the United States, provide for contract sanctity unless it hinders the effectiveness of sanctions, allow the President to consider the impact on innocent parties, and not restrict certain actions. The legislation should not impose sanctions on individuals or entities not responsible for the conduct targeted by the sanctions. It should also not restrict humanitarian aid, agricultural exports, medicine exports, or assistance aimed at changing the behavior the sanctions are meant to address. The legislation should not impose sanctions on those not responsible for the targeted conduct. It should also not restrict humanitarian aid, exports, or assistance aimed at behavior change unless in the national interest. The President must review and report on sanctions annually. The President must review and report annually on the effectiveness of imposed sanctions as a tool of US foreign policy or national security, evaluating their likely effectiveness and objectives. The President must annually review and report on the effectiveness of imposed sanctions, considering factors such as likely effectiveness, objectives, multilateral support, costs, and gains to the United States. The President must annually review the effectiveness of imposed sanctions, considering factors such as likely effectiveness, objectives, multilateral support, costs, gains to the United States, and any determination to exercise authorities under the Act. SEC. 5. GUIDELINES FOR CONGRESSIONAL CONSIDERATION OF NEW UNILATERAL ECONOMIC SANCTIONS LEGISLATION. In considering new unilateral economic sanctions legislation, Congress should ensure complete information on projected costs and gains to US national interests, take into account international legal obligations, and provide the President an opportunity to submit a report assessing such costs and gains. The President is given the opportunity to assess costs and gains, consider international legal obligations, evaluate consistency with existing sanctions, and account for administrative costs when submitting a report on proposed legislation. The costs and gains include various factors outlined in the legislation. The President must consider costs, gains, and administrative costs when evaluating proposed legislation. Factors include the likelihood of sanctions achieving objectives, national interests, and impact on humanitarian conditions. The President must consider the importance of achieving sanctions objectives, impact on humanitarian conditions, relations with allies, and national security interests when evaluating proposed legislation. The President must consider the impact on humanitarian conditions, relations with allies, and national security interests when evaluating proposed legislation. This includes diplomatic efforts and the likelihood of multilateral adoption of measures. The President must consider diplomatic efforts, multilateral adoption of measures, and potential retaliation against US interests when evaluating proposed legislation. The proposed legislation's sanctions may lead to retaliation against US interests and harm the reputation of the US as a reliable supplier of products and services. SEC. 6. CONGRESSIONAL RULES OF PROCEDURE. The House and Senate cannot consider new unilateral economic sanctions legislation unless it includes specific requirements. Any new sanctions legislation is considered a Federal private sector mandate. The Congressional Budget Office must report on the costs of proposed sanctions legislation to the US economy, including trade impact, employment, and growth. The Congressional Budget Office must report on the potential impact of proposed sanctions legislation on the US economy, including trade performance, employment, growth, international reputation, and competitive position of industries, firms, workers, and communities. This section is enacted by Congress as an exercise of the rulemaking power of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Congressional Budget Office must report on the potential impact of proposed sanctions legislation on the US economy, including trade performance, employment, growth, and competitive position of industries, firms, workers, and communities. This section is enacted by Congress as an exercise of the rulemaking power of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The rules of the House and Senate supersede other rules if inconsistent, with recognition of the constitutional right of each House to change its rules at any time. The President should adopt guidelines for imposing sanctions through Executive orders, similar to those in sections 4 and 5 of the Act. Procedures should be established for informing the public and obtaining input on sanctions policy. SEC. 8. RULES REGARDING SANCTIONS IMPOSED BY THE EXECUTIVE BRANCH OR BY STATUTORY ENACTMENTS. The President has the authority to suspend, terminate, or not impose sanctions if the gains for the United States national interests do not outweigh the costs. This includes refraining from imposing sanctions or suspending/terminating their application. Additionally, the President can also reimpose sanctions if necessary. The President has the authority to refrain from imposing or suspend sanctions, and can subsequently reimpose them with prior notification to Congress. The President can choose not to impose sanctions and can later reinstate them with advance notice to Congress. Congress can disapprove of the President's decision within 30 days by enacting a joint resolution. The President can choose not to impose sanctions, and if so, the suspension or termination would take effect 30 days after a report is submitted to Congress, unless Congress enacts a joint resolution disapproving the determination within 30 days. In cases of suspension or termination of a sanction, it will take effect 30 days after the President submits a report to Congress, unless Congress enacts a joint resolution disapproving the determination. Congressional procedures for joint resolutions differ between the Senate and the House of Representatives. The provisions of section 601(b) of the International Security Assistance and Arms Export Control Act of 1976 apply to the Senate. In the House of Representatives, a motion to proceed with a joint resolution is treated as highly privileged for quick consideration. This section supersedes any other provision of law.
